Award.AwardTitle: HCC: Small: Getting a Grip on the Numerical World: Kinestheic Interaction with Simulations to Support Collaborative Discovery in Systems Biology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Computational techniques have greatly extended the range of problems that can be solved by numerical analysis. However, few tools support the combined practice of collaborative learning and discovery in the computational sciences. This project draws on recent work in embodied cognition, which suggests that the process of building models--particularly models with dynamic visualizations--can aid conceptual understanding in complex problem domains. The researchers will develop a system to support and enhance collaborative discovery by re-representing abstract scientific problems in an embodied way. The proposed system will allow researchers to couple visuo-spatial skills with computational techniques to develop understanding and collaborate in the modeling of complex biological systems. Simultaneously, the project will develop techniques to support collaborative modeling in science and engineering. The project will thus test how theories from embodied cognition can inform interaction design and create explicit knowledge about how collaborative discovery happens in the sciences.

By changing the way abstract scientific problems and techniques are represented, the proposed system will make these scientific problem easier for researchers to understand and manipulate through embodied experience. This re-representation of complex problems may have several benefits: 1) help researchers find solutions to problems that would otherwise take too long or seem too difficult to solve; 2) enhance problem-driven learning approaches in science and engineering disciplines; 3) enable interdisciplinary groups of learners or researchers to come together and work on (and develop a shared representation of) complex problems in a hands-on manner; and 4) make complex science and engineering problems more accessible to everyday citizens. The project may also have significant impacts on emerging interactive technologies by establishing embodied cognition as a framework for interaction design.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Approach:

The use of computational techniques to understand and solve complex scientific problems in areas such as biology and medicine is critical to scientific leadership and economic competitiveness. These computational science practices draw on the skills and expertise from different science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) disciplines, with both novices and experts from multiple disciplinary backgrounds working together to solve problems. Visualization is a key part of communicating complex ideas across disciplines. However, recent work in embodied cognition suggests that visualization alone is not sufficient for learning and discovery; it is the act of building and interacting with data and models that supports conceptual understanding and leads to new discoveries. Currently, the interactive tools for working directly with large datasets, for building models, and for drawing insights from the data and models, remain limited. In this project, we investigated how emerging human-computer interaction techniques that leverage combinations of physical and digital media can help to make computational modeling of biological systems more understandable and effective, especially for novice researchers from different backgrounds, thereby facilitating learning and discovery.

Outcomes:

Our research built on ethnographic studies of the practices and problems in systems biology labs in order to design, develop and evaluate a series of prototype systems that support collaboration and modeling with large and/or complex biological datasets. Over the course of our research, we contributed novel techniques that leverage cross-device tangible and embodied interactions to allow collaborative navigation, visualization and analysis of large biological datasets, as well as modeling and simulation of biological systems. We focused on techniques that can support the modelers? ability to develop an understanding of the system they are modeling over time. This included interaction techniques for constructing models of biochemical pathways on an interactive tabletop using physical objects called ?active tangibles? (Actibles), as well as representational techniques for visualizing the models and experimental data across a large (tabletop) display surface, an interactive wall display, and small (Actible) display surfaces. Building on web based technologies for our front-end development, we iterated on the hardware and software designs to support these techniques, yielding functional prototype systems that we evaluated in user studies. The user studies helped us understand how these cross-device and collaborative interaction techniques can support the various aspects of working with large datasets and modeling complex systems, including how users can search and visualize data, how they can build and test models, and how they can track their own progress over time in order to support conceptual understanding.

Relevance:

The findings of this work are relevant for improvements of human-computer interaction, offering design considerations and interaction techniques for creating collaborative tools for the computational sciences. In particular, the systems we developed provide novel opportunities for both education and discovery in the computational sciences, and the interaction approaches we designed enable face-to-face collaboration between novices and experts around representations of complex computational problems, such as the modeling of dynamic systems. As we collect increasing amounts of data across different domains (e.g., economic, geographic, scientific, medical), these approaches can be applied to data-driven applications in different areas, and to the way people collaborate across disciplines to draw insights from data. Our use of web based technologies enables our prototype systems to work across a broad range of platforms/devices, which offers the flexibility for extending these systems to include additional interaction techniques/devices as well as to address datasets from other domain areas. In particular, our work already demonstrated the potential for extending our approaches to other related areas within computational biology, including the navigation and visualization of gene regulatory networks and the visualization and analysis of DNA and clinical datasets. More broadly, our designed approaches can be applied across a range of areas where numerical methods are used to solve complex problems.
